etymologies: mid 16th century: perhaps from Low German schuffeln ‘walk clumsily’, also ‘deal dishonestly, shuffle (cards)’, of Germanic origin; related to shove and scuffle

definitions: walk by dragging one's feet along or without lifting them fully from the ground

examples.text: I stepped into my skis and shuffled to the edge of the steep slope

shortDefinitions: walk by dragging one's feet along or without lifting them fully from ground

definitions: shift one's position while sitting or move one's feet while standing, typically because of boredom, nervousness, or embarrassment

examples.text: Christine shuffled uneasily in her chair
Ben shuffled his feet in the awkward silence

shortDefinitions: shift one's position while sitting or move one's feet while standing

definitions: put part of one's body into (an item of clothing), typically in a clumsy way

examples.text: shuffling her feet into a pair of shoes, she tiptoed out of the room

shortDefinitions: put part of one's body into item of clothing

definitions: rearrange (a deck of cards) by sliding the cards over each other quickly

examples.text: he shuffled the cards and cut the deck

shortDefinitions: rearrange pack of cards by sliding them over each other quickly

definitions: move (people or things) around so as to occupy different positions or to be in a different order

examples.text: she shuffled her papers into a neat pile

shortDefinitions: move people or things around so as to occupy different positions

definitions: play or arrange (tracks on a music player) in a random order

examples.text: the control lets you shuffle or skip songs by flicking the phone with your wrist

shortDefinitions: play or arrange tracks on a music player in a random order

definitions: sort or look through (a number of things) hurriedly

examples.text: he shuffled through the papers on his desk

shortDefinitions: sort or look through several things hurriedly

definitions: behave in a shifty or evasive manner

examples.text: Mr. Mills did not frankly own it, but seemed to shuffle about it

shortDefinitions: behave in shifty or evasive manner

definitions: get out of (a difficult situation) in an underhanded or evasive manner

examples.text: he shuffles out of the consequences by vague charges of undue influence

shortDefinitions: get out of difficult situation in underhand way

definitions: a shuffling movement, walk, or sound

examples.text: there was a shuffle of approaching feet

definitions: a quick dragging or scraping movement of the feet in dancing

examples.text: Violet tried on a top hat and did a brief vaudeville shuffle

shortDefinitions: quick dragging or scraping movement of feet in dancing

definitions: a dance performed with shuffling steps.
a piece of music for or in the style of a shuffle

examples.text: it's the usual blend of boogie, shuffle, and ballad

shortDefinitions: piece of music for or in style of such dance

definitions: a rhythmic motif based on a shuffle dance step and typical of early jazz, consisting of alternating quarter notes and eighth notes in a triplet pattern.
shortDefinitions: rhythmic motif based on such dance step and typical of early jazz

definitions: an act of shuffling a deck of cards

examples.text: the discard is removed from the deck until the next shuffle

shortDefinitions: act of shuffling pack of cards

definitions: a change of order or relative positions; a reshuffle

examples.text: the president will have to consider a cabinet shuffle in the spring

shortDefinitions: change of order or relative positions

definitions: a facility on a music player for playing tracks in an arbitrary order

examples.text: I had my iPod on shuffle and ‘Eleanor Rigby’ just happened to begin playing

shortDefinitions: facility on CD player for playing tracks in arbitrary order

definitions: a piece of equivocation or subterfuge.
